text: Bottle @ Warpigs - HF tap takeover, 2016. Clear medium yellow body with a small white head. Citrus, lemon, yeast, funk, tart, brett, hops, malt. Good.

Une bière blonde, avec une bonne effervescence, et un gros doigt de carbonatation. Au nez, levure sauvages à la HF dattaque avec un petit côté sucré et mielleux intéressant. Au goût, la levure avec une certaine influence de levures belges est bien présentes. Il y a un certain manque deffervescence en bouche, qui laisse le gout sucré des bretts prendre lascendant. Cest toutefois bien équilibré, avec le côté belge assez présent, les levures sauvages, et un aspect sucré. Une fois la bière un peu plus réchauffée, on trouve des notes de mangues bien fruitées. Néanmoins, de passer de la Edward à ça mimpressionne parce que ce sont des bières complètement différente, mais efficace.

750mL bottle. Pours amberish gold with a medium off-white head. Aroma is funk, citrus, grass, white grapes, earth, hay, and oak. Taste is barnyard, funk, earth, grapefruit, lemon, grass, apricot, some tangerine, and a little oakiness. Some pepper in the finish. Some light acidic tartness with a little lingering bitterness. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Crisp-ish mouthfeel; yeast sediment makes it a bit slicker.  As it warms the fruit brightens and the barnyard diminishes, simplifying the taste to big apricot and tangerine up front with an earthy finish. The beer feels like a combination of Edward and Dorothy (especially in the aroma), although the palate isnt quite as strong as either of those beers.

750ml 2014 bottling of E. Hasnt dried out as much as expected after all this time, and the funk level is moderate. Not a brett bomb by any means. Hop punch from release is obviously gone, now has a more rounded earthy orange character with some stonefruit and Belgian yeast spice in the finish. Also some touches of light sweet bready grain and honey notes. The fading of the hops revealed much more of a Belgian charactee than expected. Pretty balanced out right now in the profile. I preferred the somewhat dreggy pours from the second half of the bottle. Very enjoyable, but this is definitey one to drink now if youve still got it.
Sample at CBC 2016, smells like hill, funky, light sour and pleasant hoppy ending

750 ml bottle thanks to Mike! Hazy golden to orange color with off white head. Hoppy, yeasty and light malty aroma, floral, light citrusy fruity, light funky, cheesy, light vinous, wood. Sweet, light bitter and light acidic taste. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

May 12, 2016. Bottle at Hill Farmstead day at Warpigs. .
Hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is fruity with sweet notes of pineapple and peaches, bright lemon, passionfruit and orange, some funky barnyard and hay notes, light grain and herbal peppery notes. Taste is very light sweet, tart, fruity and funky. Light to medium bodied, average carbonation, slightly dry. Finish is slightly dry, some grassy and herbal bitter notes, lemon and passionfruit, some funky barnyard notes and light fruity and malty sweetness. 
Nice one!

This tastes like a Hill Farmstead beer and thats a good thing. Its cloudy w/ a creamy white head. There seems to be a lot of tropical fruit such as you get from some strains of brett. Theres definitely a bit of hops in the mix as well but its pretty subdued. There is some implied tartness by some more fruity aromas once tasted. Its a bit bitter and feels balanced and drinkable. I could drink a ton of this stuff.
750 ml bottle to snifter. Looks good; a cloudy orange with white head. Smells and tastes hoppy, funky, and oaky with a pleasantly tart medium-bodied mouthfeel. Tasty.
Tap @ CBC2016. Pours hazy orange with a medium white head. Aromas of esters, belgian style fruitiness, stone fruits, citrus, vinous. Taste is bretty, vinous, stone fruits, bitter, dark fruits.
Bottle lugged from brewery to tulip. Aroma is white grape, mild funk. Hazy golden small head. Taste is tart, dry, light berry, grape skin, wood. Prickly carbonation, dry minimally bitter finish.

Bottle sample at Warpigs/CBC week, Copenhagen - pours hazy golden amber with a beige head. Fruity and malty, barnyard and funky notes, some nice apricot, some peppery and herbal nuances into the close.

Bottle 750ml. @ [ Hill Farmsted Tape Take Over ] - Warpigs Brewpub, Flaesketorvet 24, DK-1711 Copenhagen, Denmark. [ As Hill Farmstead E. ].Unclear medium orange yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, moderate hoppy, grass, orange - citrus, dusty hops, moderate yeasty, belgium yeast, earthy notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, dusty, fruity, pale malt, grass, earthy. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20160512]

Bottle from trade from Macboost. Nose is lightly tart with a but load of Belgian yeast character. Pepper, light cardamom, coriander, crazy. Light hay. Taste is initially a lactic tartness followed by funky Brett. Hops are minimal. Ok, I guess.

Draught @ CBC 2016, Red session, København
Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, citrus, white wine, grape, tropical, yeast and funk. Taste is light to medium sweet and medium bitter with a long dry, funky, citrus, vinous and tropical finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Tap @ CBC 16. Pours hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of dank fresh juicy hops, tart vinous notes, green apples, lemon zest, juicy grapes and some sweet citrus fruits as well. The taste has a tartness to it along with the crispy juicy bitterness from the hops. Grapes, green apples, sweet citrus and slight green apples. This is extremely good!
Sample @ Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2016 Red session 20160514. Fruity, hoppy and peachy, medium body with an oily texture. The finish is dry and hoppy.

[5/12/16] Bottle at Warpigs in Copenhagen. Cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma of fruity "green" hops, funk, wood. Dry flavor, tart and bitterish, with yeast, oak, funk, wood, and bitterish fruity hops. Medium-bodied. Quite delicious.
BC16, red session, tap. Slight hazy golden with a white head. Aroma light malty, medium hoppy (citrusy) and yeasty (Bret, sour). Flavor light sweet, medium sour, light fruity and spicy. Medium body.
Bottle @ Warpigs. Hazy golden with small white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, yeast, brett, hop and lemon. Flavour is malt, fruit, yeast, little brett, medium sweet, yeast, lemon and a little bitter.
Sample @ CBC16, Copenhagen. Red session. Light hazy golden pour with a frothy head. Notes of apple skin, stone fruits, funk, light lime juice.

Sample at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2016. Hazy golden shade. Big white head. Great aroma with barrel notes. Notes of jammy fruits, fruit rind, melon, marmalade, citrus. Dry finish. Good complexity to this one.

@Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2016, REDgolden hazy. Bit funky tarty nose, pale maltd, sone hay malt strawy spicing. Med bodied, bit tart. Flavourful, straw malty. Nice allarounder.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Tap @CBC16. Hazy light amber. Fresh citrus aroma, lemon and passionfruit, funky notes. Juicy passionfruit flavour, apples, light spice. Slightly bitter and funky bite towards finish.

On tap at CBC 16. Very hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma is dank with barnyard funk, pepper, citrus, Brett and horse blanket. Flavour is light sweet and light moderate bitter. Light to light medium bodied with light carbonation.

Sample at CBC 2016. 

Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma and taste of some fruit, funk, apricot, grass and hints of bread. Fairly soft and refreshing. A good one.

duft: tropisk appelsin citrus lime
smag: citrus appelsin lime lang og frisk smag
Keg. Hazy golden, medium sized white head with good regeneration. Funk, lemon, white pepper, dry flowers, light astringency, low sweetness, medium sour, fine mouthfeel.

Tap @ CBC -16. cloudy golden body with a large fluffy white top. aroma is light peppery with red berries, hay and white grapes. taste is well balanced. some sweet fruity notes, a light sourness and a dry finish with a touch of peppers. highly drinkable. medium-light body avg co2

Pours cloudy golden with low white head 
Aromas of citrus, garden leaves, tart fruits, orange , herbs 
Taste has tart notes of citrus, green grapes , green apples, garden leaves
Tap at CBC. Pours cloudy golden with thick white head. Funky, lightly fruity, peach. Slightly tart. Nice and well balanced.
Tap@ CBC 2016. Unclear amber colored beer with a thick white head. Funky, apricotty aroma, flavor has funk, apricots, tartness and something that makes it very drinkable, refreshing. Awesome saison
Tap cbc. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma oak, tarty, fruity, hoppy, tropical, clean. Taste is tarty, fruity, tropical, light spice notes. Light vinegar.
A: Cloudy light yellow. N: Mango, orange, floral hops. T: Follows nose very well. O: Quite sweet but nice!
Bottled. Yellow coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Aroma. Citrus, sourness, brett, spice. Flavour. Grape, spice, brett, citrus, yeast. Medium to full bodied. Ends sour, citric and super dry.
Bottle at warpigs. Hoppy aroma of citrus, fruity, pine. Yeasty aroma of Brett. The flavours is mainly bitter with sour notes. Lingering hoppy bitterness. The body is light and the texture is juicy.

Bottle @ Warpigs, tap take over. Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, yeasty, bretty and moderate hoppy - citrus. Flavor is quite sweet, moderate bitter and light acidic. Dry, moderate bitter and light acidic finish. 120516
Bottle. At war pigs... Hazy Amber.. Thin white lacing... Soft zesty fruit.. Floral fruit.. Ling dry tart orange.. Light bitter.. Zezty peach.. Dry funk fruit finish

Bottle at Warpigs. It pours hazy golden with a creamy white head. The aroma is floral and tropical hoppy with light acidic notes. Tart acidic and very floral hoppy flavor. Mango, pineapple and passion fruit. Pale malty and light piney. Some acidity and it ends up fruity and bone dry. Awesome!
Bottle at Warpigs. Pours clear golden yellow with a slight white head. Aroma is is citrus zest, pepper, modest sourness, straw.

2013 batch bottle shared by a friend, poured a cloudy light golden colour with a white head. this reminds me a lot of overal, but on steroids with lots of white delicate wine barrel notes. nose of brett yeast, funk, citrus, white grapes, wine, grape skin, slight malty, crisp minerals. funky aftertaste, light tart, belgian yeasty. delicate. this is one undervalued hill farmstead beer. liked it a lot
750ml bottle pours a hazy peach color topped with a small white head. nose is a nice crisp spice light belg yeast. taste is more of the spice belg yeast and nice floral notes.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée lors dune dégustation entre amis. Arôme: Odeur de mangue et de fruits de la passion avec une pointe de miel. Apparence: La couleur est blonde voilée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de fruits tropicaux avec une pointe dorange et de miel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence dagrumes en arrière goût. (Rating #6850)

Bottle at home. Its amazing how Hill Farmsteads sour/funky beer has such a distinct aroma and taste, and E. has tons of that signature smell. Its funky and vinous, with green apple and lemon flavors and some barnyard taste. The hop bitterness from Edward is also here, but Im not sure it works quite as well -- here its a bit of a distraction from the Belgian yeast and esters. Still, this is a world-class beer.

2012 version I believe. We have a slow gusher upon popping the cap. Foamy straw colored pour. Funky nose of wet hay, lemon, and grass. Taste follows the nose with some tartness. Taste seemed a little off, so coupled with the massive carbonation, I am left to believe that either this beer doesnt age well, or I had a less than perfect bottle.

Bottled 1/26/16, drunk 3/18/16.Fantastic pour per usual. Light haze, large white head, great retention. Sparkling golden-brass body.Just a captivating nose on it. Not due to sheer force, but just so much complexity here. Theres light citrus, soft funk, earth, even light sulfur suggestions, wood, biscuit, honey, band-aid, plaster, well-water....the list goes on. Every sniff I find something new, but Id say the lemon and band-aid-like brett notes, as well as the juicy, pineapple-guava-laden hops are the largest pleasures here.Equally fun in the flavor, its nicely dry, but with a malty texture and tons of tropical fruit, band-aid, phenolic compounds (black and white pepper) and juicy hops on the end.  Some definite wood character, and a touch of toastiness, but nothing excessive.  Tight carbonation and no flaw or alcohol, the only downside is a fair bit of astringency, unable to tell whether its yeast or barrel-derived, which builds up on the finish and dulls some of the brightness/levity of the beer. Just like the bottle of The Wind I had before this, it may be my fault, having not given the bottle enough time to rest and the sediment to settle back down. I have another bottle and will be certainly updating the rating if that is the case. As is, however, this is still a supremely enjoyable, complex, drinkable beer.

Une bouteille acquise à la brasserie et dégustée le jour même en compagnie de Mademoiselle Irina et Marc-André. Un liquide brillant, orangé et pourvu dune épaisse mousse blanche tenace qui cependant glisse sur mon verre. Nous avons tous été sidérés par des arômes où les fruits côtoient la barrique dans une transcendante harmonie! Les fruits tropicaux tels la mangue, la papaye et le fruit de la passion explosent littéralement pour laisser place à une barrique réfléchie ainsi quà un funk vivant qui sy est lentement développé. Un nez absolument magnifique! Je suis dérouté lorsque je glisse mon verre entre mes lèvres. Je vis complètement autre chose. Le liquide me paraît très vineux et dense, à un point tel quil me paraît presque visqueux. Une fois lattaque vinicole passée, les houblons prennent une place de plus ne plus importante et terminent leur lente ascension en me laissant en bouche une âcreté capiteuse et pâteuse. Intéressante et surtout surprenante, cette bière dont les arômes mont séduit, manque de cohésion et de ligne directrice.

Bottle at HFS. Dark orange pour with some initial white foamy head. Smells like a hoppy Arthur - that hop and tart aroma combo. Flavor is just that. Its a hopped up, wine infused tasting saison-y ale. Taste lingers and the hop really hits home in the beginning but fades to this nice tart wine flavor.

750ml bottle shared with Seb and bought yesterday at he brewery. Aroma: nice apples, floral, white wine, oaky giving some vanilla aroma. Really reminds me of the TDD X. App: hazy orange, small white head, thick lacing. Taste and palate: medium body, really vinous, silky, light bitter and subtle sour finish. Overall: great stuff. Really reminds me of TDD X. Great stuff. Would like it to be a bit less bitter but still, this is pretty good.
Shared at Zwanze 2015, I think its probably not as interesting as it might have been fresher when the hops were much more alive. Its still pretty damn good.
Happy to get to try this. A very well made beer that has characteristics of a pale, but is more like a saison. Funky nose, and tastes good, but not great.

14 release. Pours an orange color with a creeping head. Also a slow gusher from the bottle. Aromas of fruity yeast, some hops. Heavy funk with a load of brett. Taste is funky and dusty with fruity and floral hints. Pretty dry with a medium body. Seems like the Brett has eaten most of the residual sugar which prompted the gushing action along with the over attenuation, which really works well here actually. This is god nectar.

750 mL bottle. Batch 1. Originally reviewed 5/25/2013. Its a hazy orange with a huge off white head. It slowly oozes out of the bottle pushing gunky crap with it. Sticky lacing.

Extremely bretty aroma, but lots of flavor behind it. Still some hops there. Lots of citrus.

Taste is Earthy and very bretty. Mimics the nose almost identically. Citrus more prominent. Lots of earthiness in the finish. Slight bitterness.
 Medium body. Well carbonated but not overly so.

 Arguably better than Mimosa. Has more complexity than Mimosa because of the fresh hop character, even at this age.
Hazy golden with a foamy sticky white head. Amazing aroma of earthy sourness and sweet pink Chapstick. In a good way. Smooth Belgian musty funk flavor with bright yeasty tones and an earthy malt.

Bottled. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is wood, mild spices, some mild acidic notes as well. Flavour is wood, spices, herbs and some floral notes. Quite fruity and earthy aftertaste. Wellbalanced, but not the best of HF beers.

(Bottle, 0.75 l - 2014 vintage, at laitis, 20150613, thanks) The beer poured golden and cloudy. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had tartness, fruitiness, dry wood-like scents and apple seeds. Palate was medium bodied and dryish with medium carbonation. Flavours were fruitiness, tartness, wood-like dryness, sourness and bitterness. Aftertaste was fruity, sour and hoppy. Very well done balanced brew with tartness and hoppiness.

750ml bottle - thanks VastActiv!
Hazy pale orange, but as this was a gusher I have to punish it (-1 to look), brief head. Pleasant apricotty wood aged, bretty, aroma. Sharp palate, refreshing, and nice carbonation. Sharp acidic taste, fruity and apricotty, but predominantly acidic. A strange sour/pale ale hybrid, not entirely sure this is what the brewer was aiming for, in particular if he doesnt have enough control over the process to keep the beer in the bottle upon opening. Not sure what the fuss is about, this is only decent, nothing to gush over.

750ml bottle (2014 vintage) @Laitis, thanks. Cloudy orange color. Medium size, white head, stays. Sour, fruity, vinegar and orange in aroma. Fruity, citrus, oranges, sour, vinegar and bit leather in taste. Sour fruits in aftertaste. Dry mouthfeel. Not for my taste.

75 cl bottle @ home, bottled 2014. Thanks jtclockwork & VastActiv!
Aroma has strong earthy notes, citrus and grapefruit. Feels like a farmhouse saison. Flavour is tart with strong earthy notes, lots of citrus, some grapefruit and orange. Dry finish. Very tart and citrusy. And very farmhouse.

Bottle 0.75l at Laitis, Helsinki. Vintage 2014. Thanks to jtclockwork! Colour is deep golden with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, citrus, sourness, some wood, juicy sweetness and some malts. Excellent.

750ml bottle, 2014 vintage. Thanks VastActiv!
Pours yellowish orange with a massive foamy head.
Aroma of oak, ripe fruits, yeast, earthy notes, spices, hops, bretta, hints of herbal notes and grass.
Taste is funky yeasty, farmyardy and earthy with some bretta, oak, wood, fruits, grass and herbal notes.
Finish is funky, woody, oaky and rustic with some bretta, ripe fruits and funky yeastiness. Pretty good.
Golden pour, wispy white head. Nose is funk, lemon rind, yeasty. Taste is barnyard, yeasty, citrus, soapy. Light mouthfeel.

750 bottle, dark lord line share. Cloudy light yellow. In one word its yeasty. Barnyard, pepper, dry white wine. I guess for me it has way to much of the Brett and barnyard stuff going on and not enough sour to balance it out. Not that there is anything wrong with that. Probably more wrong with me.

2014 Bottle into an HF glass. Pours golden with a white head. Aromas of HF yeast, Brett, musty funk, citrus. Taste is similar. Lots of musty funk in the taste up front; lightly bitter, some citrus, finishes tart. A lot more funk than I normally enjoy in my beers.... Would love to have tried this when fresh.

Bottle split at Bruces pad - for the last time, big thanks to Padraig, 27/03/15.
Hazed orange with a decent off white covering.
Nose is light piss, tangy apricot, melon, straw, funk, tangerine.
Taste comprises bitter citric rinds, peach, straw, funk, Belgian yeast esters, spice, darker fruit notes, candyfloss.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, light hop presence in a drying close.
Solid Belgo offering.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 27th March 2015Swan Song at Bruces. Thanks to Manny G. Hazy gold beer, small pale cream colour head. Nose of mild piss and sweet malts. Palate is airy and semi dry. Decent fine carbonation. Light dry malt cream. Mildly sour orange and lemon. Some peel. Little yeast. Light bitterness in the airy dry finish. Nice flavour and pretty drinkable, the nose a bit pissy.

Bottle share, thanks to MannyGoldberg. Hazy yellow, lightly sparkling, small foamy white head. Aroma has some peach, dry, lemon flavoured biscuits. Body is medium, slightly foamy, low carbonation. Taste is soft with some straw, minerals, grapefruit, a little caramel, finishes dry. Nice.

Bottle, batch 2. Thanks to Manny G. It pours cloudy golden-orange with a small white head. The nose is earthy, doughy, bitter-sweet, pissy, dank, peach, nectarine, apricot yoghurt, manure and light spice. The taste is crisp, tart, juicy, earth, funk, gooseberry, funk, damp leaf, must, spice and mouldy action with a dry, woody finish. Medium body and average carbonation. Solid musty action.

Bottle. April 2014 batch shared with my wife and sent to me by Tom and Pat thanks guys! Apperance is cloudy yellow with frothy white head that is there to last. Aroma is grape must, citrus funk, melon, and lime. Taste is light citrus funk, white wine, melon, finishes dry, crisp, and clean with hint of lingering bitterness. Body is a touch thin, lots of carbonation, overall this is very well done!

Bottle: I believe this is the 2012 batch? Thanks to Kevin. Golden-yellow body with lighter straw hints. Volatile, huge eggshell-white head grows large, cloudy, & foamy, leaving fat chunks of lacing as it slowly recedes. Aroma is like a huge bouquet of roses. Super floral. Wet flowers & bitter, zesty grass. Successive whiffs reveal a more rounded hop character with underlying tones of earth, dirty, farmhouse musk, wet wood, & touches of uneasy Brett. Light apple skin & pear fruit in the back-end, still underpinned by a large, floral bitterness. Flavor is largely floral & bitterly botanical as well. Slightly vegetal at times, but mostly comprised of flower petals, grass, & rosewater. Perfumey, weedy, grassy, bitter, zesty hops ring throughout. Mild citrus zest shines through at times with a touch of hefty funk & wet oak that only shows up near the finish. Sharp, heavily carbonated, dry finish. Good, but it would benefit from a little less bitterness abrasion & some amped up farmhouse tones.

From a 75 cl bottle, courtesy of _angst_. CLoudy golden, medium white head. Fruity aroma with vegetative bretty notes. Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation. Dry with medium bitterness, somewhat clashing with the (albeit soft) acidity. My lest favourable HF beer so far.

(Bottle) pours hazy orange with a white head. The aroma holds funk, citrus, fruits, white bread and crackers. Fantastic nose. The flavour is near dry, light to medium bitter and light to medium acidic. Fruity, tight malty and funky. The mouthfeel is clean and mineraly with a near medium carbonation. Citric finish. Light to medium bodied.

Bottle receive in trade. Pours very hazy pale golden with a frothy white head that while leaving some sticky lacing and trace on the glass. Smell is fruity and funky with crackers, pink grapefruit, pineapple, passion fruit, star fruit, dry soil, hay, barnyard, kumquats and lemon zest. Taste is slightly sour, fruity and funky with crackers, grapefruit, pineapple, passion fruit, star fruit, lemon juice, dry soil, hay, barnyard and lemon zest. Mouthfeel is soft, dry, tart and light to medium bodied. Finish is slightly sour with crackers, grapefruit, pineapple, passion fruit, dry soil, hay, leather, barnyard and lemon zest. Really damn good!

Bottle at An afternoon of Skulls, Scotsman and Speedway 141129. Thanks Alex! Hazy golden beer with a rich lasting offwhite head. Sourish fruity aroma, citrus, grass, hay, biscuits, lemongrass, floral notes, peach notes, some passion fruit. Sourish fruity flavor, grassy, citrus, peach, yeasty, passion fruit, lemongrass, grapefruit, floral notes, dandelions, spicy notes. Very good.

Bottle at Øl & Brød - Hill Farmstead Dinner. Cloudy amber - white head. Orange. Citrus. Fruity. Wheaty notes. Flowery. Zesty. Ok light bitter-ish notes. High dryness. Light sweet notes. Wooden. Light grapey notes. Fantastic.
Dégustation chez Charles. Belle robe, arôme de levures sauvages, houblon et un peu de céréales. En bouche, des notes de fruits jaunes, houblon frais, Brett. Excellente.

Bottle at Hill Farmstead Beer Makers Dinner at Øl & Brød October 11th. Pours a deep orange with a frothy white head. Aromas of orange, funk, honey, citrus and kiwi. Taste is orange, honey, funk, citrus, kiwi and some slight vinous notes. Mouthfeel is crisp and dry with medium carbonation.

Bottle, both batches 1 and 2. Both legit as hell. Big funky lemon aroma, bright and yeasty. Dry, tart, lemon flavor. Slight bitterness on the finish with loads of funk. Dry, lively, biting mouthfeel. Damn good beer. Damn good.

Pours hazy golden with low white head. Aroma of fresh grass, citrus, elderflower, grapes, peach. Taste is funky light tart, very balanced, with slight sweet finish. Light, crisp body with soft carbonation.

Hazy golden colour, white head. Aroma of hops, quite floral, bit sweet, light sour note. Light sour flavour, bitter hops. Bitter hoppy finish. (from 75cL bottle @ ZBF Leuven. Thanks for sharing, tderoeck!)

Serving: Bottle. It pours a hazy orange with a soft and lasting white head. Light stone fruit, hay, fresh cut grass, dusty yeast, and a little funk in the nose. Bright and effervescent on the tongue. Nice peach and nectarine skin notes with a bit of barnyard and hay. Finishes dry. Very nice indeed.

Bottle generously shared by Adam at Zwanze Day. Cloudy yellow pour with a white head. Mild lemon and citrus aromas. So good. Complex with lemon zest, citrus, and mild sour barnyard notes. Yeast and oak lowlights. Above average body and mouthfeel.

Hazy golden with a good pale head. Aroma is apricot, peach, spice, some brett, pear. Medium-light bodied, spicy on the palate, lightly dry finish.  Taste is peach, apricot, spicy saison, brett. Delicious.

Bottle thanks to agentzigzag! Pours hazy golden amber, medium off white creamy head, nice lacing. Aroma is Bretty, musty, citrus and grapefruit notes as well. Reminds me of Anchorage Brett strain. Flavor has a light bretty funk, lightly bitter with plenty of citrus notes. Minerally, as is my usual impression of HF beers, perhaps a very light saltiness at the end. Medium body, silky mouthfeel. This is a hell of a beer. I wish I could buy it in six packs.
Hazy yellow pour. Small white head. Little lacing. Malty aroma with some citrus. Taste is malty with a slight sour twang.

Cloudy golden color, foamy. Fruity aroma, citrus but i cant pin down the source, tiny bit of funk. Nice bitter yet fruity flavor. Super drinkable, really like this one though i would like it slightly drier.
Blonde with a nice head. Aroma is very peachy (!) with loads of grass, barnyard, countryside. Peaches on the tongue, nice carbonation, funky but balanced. World class

Oh, so this is what ousts Orval out of its #1 style spot?
Pours a very hazy blonde with a small head & some nice lacing on the glass.

The aroma is bright and peachy, it has some lemon and new oak, some musty basement and some chillin in a barn style funk. 

The flavor is tart and peachy. Its earthy with a great minerallity & lemon rind. Its lightly sour & quite delicious. 

Its really great, its not "knock Orval down an notch" great... but its delicious.

Bottle shared by yourefragile. Thanks Michael.

The beer is light orange and hazy with a white head. Aromas include wine, honey, grass, sunshine, citrus. Smells great. Similar flavor. lemons and grass with citrus and floral notes. Medium bodied and tangy. Another fabulous saison from Hill Farmstead.

750 ml bottle shared by yourefragile, thanks Moll. Pours a hazy translucent golden yellow with last ring of off white edge head. Aroma is citrus tang, funk, hay and grass, and tropical fruit juice with peaches. Flavor is same, with slight peppery Belgian yeast. Bright carbonation, vegetal grassiness, medium bodied and tangy finish. Delicious.

Bottle, shared at RBAG 2014 by Steve. Cloudy light orange. Enticing aromas of guava, funk, and grass. Hoppy, funky, lightly skunky with flavours of green mango, grapefruit, grass, and funky earthy/barny undertones. Complex and delicious.

This beer poured cloudy and murky the color of grapefruit juice and had a big head with good retention and lace. It was definitely my least favorite beer form Hill Farmstead. This beer has a mellow smoothness from the aging in oak, a prominent woody flavor and one heck of a sharp hop bitter in the finish. The fruit flavors were also mellowed in the drink but luckily it still had some juicy tartness. Bone dry. I think the bitter does eclipse the fruitiness and the pepper in the finish. As it drank the bitter became unconscionable. The mouthfeel of the beer was uncomfortably dry and powdery. It had a dominant floral rather than a fruitiness. Some orange peeks out as it warms but its mostly lemony. Its ok but my favorite is Edward.

Fully hazed, brilliant yellow-orange pour gathers a rocky, lathery head.  A quick whiff of funk quickly gives way to the brightest golden kiwi and pineapple aroma I can remember.  A blanketing of tough to find herbs and spices comes next; tarragon, clove, white pepper and dandelion.  Citrus and stone fruit notes flash like meteors.  This is a connection of quieted hops and brilliant yeasts that just thrills the imagination with its soft layering of herbal notes and pungent, rather indescribable moments of rustic funk.

The flavor is enormous but reserved like a young Orval.  First is a white pepper dusted apricot flavor, distinct and quiet.  Very light resiny hop oils surrounding it, and some dry green herbs.  Myriad stone fruits.  Gorgeous lavender.  Banana.  Gravelly and brittle.  The yeast doesnt flex much yet, and so what we have is a lovely, quiet showing of hops gathered up in the dimly seen funk of the brett.  Its like a fresh farm with no animals.

Texture is light and young; punchy with light acids and hops.  Gruyere rind and pineapple finish, leaving an oily, rubbery texture grabbing every corner of my mouth.  This is delicious, and it doesnt have it together yet.  Theres so much hop, so much saison yeast, and when the funk arrives it will just fucking kill it.  And right now, it still kind of does.

Batch #2 bottle shared by Shaun Hill during Philly Beer Week.

A - Pours slightly hazed golden yellow with a nice one finger tall white head leaving spotty trails of lace down most of the glass.

S - Smells of damp earth, musty funk, spicy belgian yeast, and a nice strong fruit aroma - mainly apples and oranges. The hops are there but the other aromas drown them out a bit.

T - Starts off with the musty funk and wet earth from the aroma combining with the bready yeast and light spice to form the saison base. The fruit and hops come through toward the end of each sip, leaving the palate dried after each sip.

M - Light, smooth body with moderate carbonation. Nice crisp feel with a dry finish.

O - I only got a sample of batch one but I thought it was pretty good. Now that I got to try a proper pour I can really really see what this one is all about. The flavors work very well together and make a really awesome beer.

750 ml shared by Tooch. Thanks, buddy! Pours a well hazed orange amber hue, big hazy body with darkness in the middle with big cakey offwhite head. Huge cakey elements with firm lacing, big and sticks around well. Aromas are richly dry and spicy, gentle funk with some melon and orange fruity elements. Gentle yeast, touches of brett, orange and lemons. Richer florals and that Galaxy element gives a firm fruity bitterness. Initial is medium bodied, a touch lighter. Gentle yeast, richer citrusy orange and lemon, touches of spice, bready malts. Richer Galaxy fruity elements, touches of melon, firm citrus, and gentle florals. Really nice. Galaxy element, touches of spice, with, richer florals, and melon, lemons, touches of orange. Grapefruit, touches of funk, dry peppery yeast. Wow. What a beer.

750ml bottle pours a hazy, bright yellow with some creamy, white head.  Nice floral nose, fruity, light onion, lemon, punchy, light pine, very hoppy but very approachable.  Flavor is peppery, lightly herbal, hoppy, lightly sweet, honey, orange, champagne grapes.  Medium bodied, zesty finish.

Pour at Scotts saison tasting, pour out of bottle is hazy orange-yellow with white head, aroma has notes of white wine, tart fruits, oak, funky earth, some lemon and lactic notes, some grass, spice, cat pee notes from some of the hops.  Taste is a mix of sweet fruit, cat pee hops, funky earth, wine and biscuit and bready yeast.  Interesting.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a medium sized frothy tan head. Big floral and tropical notes in the aroma along with earth, mint, honey, fresh citrus. The taste is bitter citrus, lime zest, pale malts, peppery and herbal notes. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness. Nice beer.

750 thanks to Matt! Big yeasty and fruity aroma. Grapes. Oranges. Some funk from the brett that leaves that tang and bit of spice. Yeast. Dry, but not super dry. Just another fantastic saison/farmhouse from HF.

Yeah another winner.  Hazy light gold pour, with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is loaded with yeast funk, horse blanket, hay, spicy and lively hops.  Flavor is a wonderful blend of saisony funk and good hops.  So lively on the tongue, so mild yet assertive.  Bold and restrained.  HFS just rocks.

Purchased at some point in May at Hill Farmstead. 2012 Vintage stored in the cellar and placed in the fridge a few hours before opening. Served with my GF in a Hill Farmstead Glass.

A - Deep orange & golden glow with a slight level of clouds / haziness. Head was a bit thick since I poured sort of vigorously. Had a 3 finger head that subsided semi-fast to about 1 finger after 3 minutes. Lacing was nice with lots of tight bubbles in an off-white colour.

S - Crazy nice smell! Very nice spice and belgian yeast. Slight bit of funky barnyard scent, very akin to a dry white wine on the back of my nostrils and really mellow hop profile but enough to contribute nicely to the scent.

T - Wow. Pretty remarkable. Um, very nice grassy and earthy taste, minor up-front tartness with a smooth mellow bitter hop taste on the finish. Reminds me a lot of chewing on straw or tobacco leaves. Slight bit of peppery goodness and a really nice wild funky belgian yeast that leaves the finish smooth and tasty.

M - 100% carbonation on the mouth swish. Medium body and grassy hoppy taste as it goes down.

O - This is pretty incredible. Stoked I have two of them. Very very nice!

At Tria Fermentation.  Poured an apricot color with a long lasting medium sized white head, noticeable lacing, and active carbonation.  Aroma includes citrus notes floral hops, and enjoyable grassy barnyard funk.  Complex taste is filled with nectarine, citrus, tart fruits, and subtle funk before a smooth, dry finish.

Bottle from joeybones3.  Bright golden-orange pour with a huge clumpy head.  The aroma is wonderful; floral, grass, spices, white wine, oak, cotton candy, and funky yeast notes. Lots going on for sure.  This is dry, spicy, and a bit tart in the mouth.  Clean and very dry finish.  Nice array of flavors here; straw, grass, lots of brett, lavender and other herbal notes, flowers, bitter orange peel, zesty hops.  This tastes like something that might come from Anchorage Brewing, based on my limited experience with the brewery.  Nice beer.

Bottle shared by Dak @ nbutler11s bachelor party!  Golden tangerine pour with a nice eggshell head.  Dusty, dank, dirty hops along with some floral notes and pungent herbs.  Definitely get the Brett.  Bit of barnyard.  Tasty.

Thanks to Dak for the share!  Pours a hazy orange-peach color with an eggshell head.  Aroma is some dank hops, funk and some herbiness.  Taste is sweet with more fruits and spice.  Dry finish.  Pretty tasty stuff here.

750 ml bottle poured a hazy gold with a lasting creamy white head. Aromas of barnyard funk, straw, earthiness, yeast and citrus. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of straw, yeast, earthiness and light citrus with a smooth dry lingering funky finish.
Super floral nose with dusty cobwebs and cellar notes, touch of citrus. Dry, hoppy funky, horsey. Very nice.

Bottle @ Scotts Summer Saison tasting. Thanks so much Scott! Cloudy yellow/orange appearance with a white head. Somewhat leafy, a bit piney, earthy hoppy, tart tangerine citrusy aroma. Fairly earthy/herbal, lemon citrusy, leafy, tart flavor. Good but I found Mimosa better.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2013 mimosa aged batch 750ml bottle.  pours a hazy dark orange with a huge cratered offwhite and mocha head.  slowwww gusher.  beautifully complex floral bouquet of bright floral hibiscus and a a touchy of juicy peaches.  pleasant dry melon kissed bubblegum sweetness.   cut super nicely by a clean, complex onslaught of fresh cut grass, old farm hay,  funky fog, lemongrass, and pleasant flowery rose pedal to round things out.    wonderful.    taste is dry, crisp clean grass, hay,   rye, and dank resin. hoppy.  dank.  bone dry.  real nice.     wow.   takes orval to school.   amazing beer.  this just might be the best beer ive ever had.   just about perfect in every way.   beyond complex, in a fun, exciting tasty way.   juicy, dry, funky, floral.  bright resin.   really fun beer to drink.   holy tamole peggy sue.

GUSHER!
Orange with a huge head. Brett and Citrus smell, mostly citrus and hops in the flavor. Dry and crisp. Tasty but not overly special.
75cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2011, with Brettanomyces, thx to Secret Santa!, complex brew, malty/bitter and slightly fruity/vinous, balanced, cloudy, rocky head, good brew, yet expensive!

First beer of the day (like most other people it seemed) at the anniversary party.

Light golden colored, hazy body with a massive, dense rocky bone white head. Head takes forever to die down and leaves behind airy clumps of lacing throughout the glass. Aroma is light and delicate blend of barnyard and fruit. Initially muted earthy notes of grass, hay and brett subtly mix with apple, orange and citrus peel. Flavor takes a similar route, initially grassy and subtly funky before light citrus and spice clean up the finish. Trace bitterness or alcohol, this was very refreshing and almost sleight to a fault. Oops, tastes like someone got some Orval in my Dupont.

Bottle. Pours a nice golden orange color with a rocky white head. Aroma is a lot like orval, I get lots of brett, barnyard and musty cellar aromas, along with some sweet malt, a good hop backbone of pineapple orange and lemon, I also get some white grapes and vinous notes. The flavor follows the nose with the hop backbone of pineapple, orange and lemon, then lots of brett, barnyard, wet hay, musty old flavors and the vinous white grape notes. The body is medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a great Orval style beer, it reminds a little of Mikkeller Its Alive and USAlive.

2012 bottle.  Pours a straw golden color with billowy foamy head.  Aroma is huge citrus and funk with light herbal and bready notes.  Taste is amazing.  Orange dominates at the start but the beer finishes super dry with medium brett funkyness and a light hop/orange zest bitterness at the finish.  This beer is close to perfection.
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2015 Mimosa aged batch. Orval can go suck a dick. This is how its done. Orange aroma, merange head. Brett and dry flavors with some oranges in the background. Dericious.

From notes.  First reviewed 9/20/2011.  Poured from a 750 caged and corked into a tulip.

E. has a very nice cloudy orange tangerine color with a frothy white head. Like I have come to expect in the style, there is a nice amount of lace that clings to my glass.

Dry saison yeast, biscuit malt, pepper, pineapple, grapefruit citrus, and a little bit of funk contribute to the nose.

The first flavor to hit my tongue is a light caramel sweetness. A little bit of pepper and spice, then toward the end the flavor turns a little bit sour and some funk comes out. Some fruit is soft - peach, grapefruit, apricot.

Dry and light bodied, with a carbonation that is both somewhat crisp and creamy.

This is too dry for my taste, and it seems like the beer loses focus.

Bottle, from (if memory serves) Fred82. It was either Fred or Dany, but you know those French Canadiens: They all look alike. ( I have seen neither Dany nor Fed in the flesh, nor pictures of them, but you know what I mean). Shared with Scott and Kris, which apparently means Im not part of the "Winnipeg Crew", which is something Im oddly very proud of. Fine gentlemen both. Pours hazy, almost cloudy honey-gold, with a thick cream-coloured head and amazing lacing. Nose is bretty/funky, with fading hops, sour cream, apricots, clean baking powder biscuit notes along with some breadiness, some mineral and earth as well. Flavours of spicy earth, stonefruit, fig/prune, jam, funk, bitter walnut; Finish is nutty and and spicy, rather lingering. Killer.

2011 Vintage (batch 1) - Poured into a Drie Fonteinen tumbler.  Huge, three finger, frothy, white head.  Body is a hazy rustic orange.  Lots of lacing.  Earthy grains on the nose with a nice helping of brett and some musty hops.  Great outdoor aroma.  Feels like summertime.  The flavor has changed quite a bit since I had this almost a year ago.  Lots of orange zest citrus, but more of the peel bitterness is making its way to the front.  The hops have a very herbal quality to them, similar to some of the notes I get from the various Fantome saisons.  The brett is definitely coming through more.  Nice and dry.  I loved this fresh, but I think its gotten even better.  The body and carbonation are spot on.  Definitely a different brew with a year on it, but I really like the change.  Wish this wasnt my last bottle.  Definitely need to pick up a few more of these at this years release.  Would love to see this beer with 2-3 years of age on it.

Bottled sample via Savvy1982. Shared with oakbluff and Savvy1982. Gold in colour with strong carbonation. Aromas are of Rocket candies, pale malt, wildflowers, leathery brett, and a bit of bread dough. Quite minerally on the palate, with notes of pale malt, fuzzy fruit, nettles, and a touch of either creamy lacto or fading hops on the back end. Fairly dry with a nice bitter finish. Starting to fade, but stil pretty good.

Pours gorgeous light acorn amber with lively bubbles, huge frothy head with great retention and lacing.  Aroma is fresh, earthy brett, light grains, herbal hops and pleasant orange citrus notes.  Additional hops, more piney and citrus-like in character, come out as the beer warms.  Taste has big funk, grassy, herbal hop bitterness contrasted by light fruitiness,  with a dry brett finish.  Crisp and lively in the mouth without being too thin.  Great brew.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2012 750ml bottle, 1st bottled batch, courtesy 4.4-40.  The pour yields a hazy, dark, glowing orange amber body with a tall, frothy, creamy-beige head.  Slowly, the foam fades to a small, lumpy layer, leaving wet, splotchy spots of lace on the glass.  The aroma is based in fresh, pale, lightly caramelized cereal grains, sweet cracker, and bread.  Overlying hops suggest of pithy, peppery orange peel, moderately catty at points and fairly dry throughout.  A prominent, fruity, somewhat creamy yeast profile rounds things out, drawing everything together nicely.  Flavors show more of the biting, pithy hops, loaded with orange peel and suggesting of secondary dry grasses.  Yeast is delectably fruity, toughing on citrus but also some distant tropical fruit.  Malts are again crackery and softly sweet, yet dry, reminding me of Cuban Crackers in some ways.  In the mouth, the body feels mostly dry, with fine, moderately paced carbonation and a zippy, peppery finish.  Another damn fine brew from Shaun Hill.  Good stuff.750ml bottle, 2nd bottled batch.  This one was quite a bit different than batch 1.  First off, it gushed - nay, oozed a like a slow-smoldering, frothy volcano. Brettanomyces is instantly present, and in fact, quite dominant. Dusty hay and farmhouse air are prominent.  Dried pineapple plays a huge role.  Bold hop notes show more tropical notes, though pithy lemon is still present.  Yeast is intensely fruity and dusty...wild yet masterfully tamed.  Damn fine Belgian style brett pale.  Nods to Bam Biere, Orval, and other classics...but stands out on its own.

Bottle  Fantômepalooza 2011 Pours cloudy and amber with a mid-sized, creamy, khaki head. Good retention. The aroma is so nice and roasty  mocha, chocolate crème and vanilla. Medium-bodied with active carbonation. The flavor is fruity, bitter, bready and mildly acidic. Tangy, bitter, yeasty finish. Kudos to GoT for sharing this beer!

Notes from the anniversary event on Memorial Day weekend....Pours thick cloudy orange amber with a frothy head. The aroma has a nice funky, psicy, yeast profile to it. There are funky and hoppy flavors blended together perfectly  on a smooth, medium body.

In short: An Ovalesque funky hoppy beer.  Fantastic.
How: Bottle 750ml.  A few times.  This rating for a bottle consumed 1.5 month after the beer release
The look: Cloudy orange-blonde body
In long: Nose is bretty-hoppy with strong notes of leathery funk, grapefruits, dry wild flowers.  Taste is more or less the same, a nice bed or crunchy dry cereals, a lot of funk, leather, lots of bitter grapefruits, dry flowers.  Very lively Belgian style mouthfeel and carbonation.  The beer has morphed over the few months since its release, the funk is really coming out strong and the beer is now bone dry.  Both the hops and funk are converging towards grapefruis and leather.  Comparison to Orval is unavoidable and for good reason.  When listing the individual flavor elements one by one it reads like two different beers yet somehow when I look at the big picture I cannot help but to think American Orval.  This is a fantastic beer. 
 "GIVE ME AN E! ... GIVE ME ANOTHER E! ... GIVE ME ANOTHER E! ... GIVE ME ANOTHER E! ... GIVE ME ANOTHER E! ... "  me if I was a Hill Farmstead cheerleader

750 ml bottle shared with the group.  Pours a hazy golden amber color with a large fluffy white head.  Someone in our group described the aroma as "a fresh bag of weed in the middle of a stinky farmhouse".  I cant comment on the first part, but from my perspective this had barnyard, horse blanket, funk, herbs, earthy hops and some Brett.  The flavor is earhty, dry, herbal (sage), Brett notes, some mild fruit and grass.  This gets a touch sweeter as it warms.  I really enjoyed the complexity of this beer.  I didnt know what to think about this one going in and even after having it, dont really know how to describe it completely.  Ill simply say that I liked it.

bottle... golden body with some copper a bit of an off color, good carbonation as there is a lot but the off white head is a touch thin... the nose is a touch to yeasty, taste is merely ok, blah... solid but one of my least favorite HF
(Draught)  Pours a cloudy yellow body with a medium white head.  Aroma of barnyard, florals, stone fruit, lacto, apricot, pineapple.  Flavor of brett, citrus, florals, grass, mango, and pineapple.

Big thanks to ShaunE himself for the bottle. 750ml offering. Pours out a somewhat clear golden yellow hue with a large frothy white head that holds for a while. Smell is very funky with lots of tropical fruit. pineapple horse blanket. grassy scent. Taste is clean funk with bready malt. fruit esters of pineapple and citrus funk.  mouthfeel is medium light body and very crisp, dry ending. Overall another enjoyable offering.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2012 On tap at the Hill Farmstead Anniversary Celebration. Served in a Hill Farmstead long-stem tulip.

Pours a bright yellow-golden color that is mostly clear with a really nice white head. Loads of foam and lacing. Early pour from the keg that was mostly foam to start, but really nice retention. The nose carries a good dosing of funk along with some light floral hops and a good dosing of stone fruits. Some citrus as well. Nice funk throughout. Really really nice nose. The flavor has a moderate amount of funk and good hop flavor, but doesnt quite hit the level of the nose. Body is dry and funky with a good background bitterness. Dry finish. Light body. Delicious.

Serving type: on-tap

Bottle sent & shared by Derek, thanks for the HFS hookup! Smell is a super earthy funk and some wine grapes. Taste is much lighter in comparison to the nose with a light, funky bitterness that goes the distance. Very earthy with a touch of pine. Real easy to drink.

Bottle shared with friends. Poured a clear orange with a pink hue and a white head that lasted throughout the beer. Aroma had a good amount of funk on it with some nice light pine and citrus hops as well as a nice oak backing. Flavor was similar with funk mixing nicely with the pine hops and just a bit of supporting citrus and oak.

Pour from a bottle revealed a hazy gold orange. nice white head. Aromas of Brett and fresh earthy citrus. Medium on the palate . Bitter, hops in a dry fashion. Herbal grassy flavors along with the funk quality. Lemon, citrus fruit well crafted tasty beer.

Bottle at a Max tasting. Pours a full pale gold with rocky white head. Aroma is some bretty funkiness, juicy passion fruit, and banana. The flavor is delicious and juicy: fresh orange juice and yeast. A touch of hops with banana near the end of an overall funky and dry finish. Light body. Quite juicy and quite good.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured clear copper color with a large frothy off-white head that was lasting with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy sweet malt, brett, earthy leaves aroma. Medium to full body with a slick dry texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sour & bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy sour & bitter finish of moderate to long duration. My expectations where exceeded with a standout change of pace brew.

Aroma has some spice, very earthy aspects, a little funky and dry with citrus, some odd herbal quality on the taste. Maybe I needed to have this earlier but to me it was not too easy to drink, a little sharp. Would love to try again.

Draft, RBSG bus trip.  Medium off-white head, cloudy, amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, apricot, pineapple, light spicy.  Taste is moderately sweet, grapefruit, pineapple.  Soft medium body, light resin.
on tap @Capones RBSG-pours a white head and yellow/gold color.  Aroma is pineapple, secondary light malt.  Taste is pine/pineapple hops, light malt.

Draft at Capones during the RBSG 2011 bus tour. Poured a hazy orange body with a foamy white head. Aroma of wild wet flowers, brett, and ketchup. Thinner bodied with fizzy carbonation. Once really loving the flavor on this one, wild flowers, lavender notes and lots of brett. Meh at best, this was not for me.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2012 Tap at Capones. Hazy orange-gold, frothy white head, heavy lace. Nose is heavy Brett, mango, sea shells and light paper with glue. Lots of mango and hay, lightest rind, short dry finish. Too effervescent, makes flavor appear even thinner.

This poured a cloudy yellow color with an off white head, very small. Aroma was light belgian yeast and medium citrusy hops, just a boquet andd earthy aromas. Flavor was alot like orval very light funy, yeast and belgian spices melded perfectly with piney citrusy hop flavors but not bitter. Great Stuff.
Capones, RBSG.  Deep orange with small white head.  Nose is just lovely--strong brett, pineapple, dry hops.  I love this combo.  Flavor is  some citrus, brett deliciousness.  Yum.

From bottle at Capones. Poured a medium to deeper, cloudy/hazy, golden color with a medium sized off white head. Aromas of brett, funk, citrus, fruity, and yeast. Tastes of the same brett/funkiness, citrus, spicy, and yeast. Lacing left on the glass.
Bottle at Capones. Pours clear gold. White head. Nose/taste of Brett, light lemon, pineapple, caramel, yeast and apricot. Some light funk. Medium body.
Orange yellow pour with creamy off white head. Nice Belgian yeast aroma and some floral notes. Wheaty, paper, and Belgian yeast flavor. Medium body with good carbonation. Nice beer.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2012 750mL from Capones for RBSG 2011 Philly/Philly Beer Week. The pour is a cloudy dark orange with a thick, off-white, creme head. Giant lacing everywhere. Nose is funky kumquat but citrus hoppiness takes over. As it opens up the funk shines through with hints of oddities like tomato and celery and paper. Taste is more IPA to me with citrus and kumquat soft hoppiness. Very nice. 6/6/2011 7/5/7/4/14=3.7750mL batch 2 thanks to oteyj. Beautiful pour. Rocky enormous white head. Mega retention. Full haze pineapple sorbet srm. Nose is herbal, sage, pineapple upside down cake. Taste is mega crisp and refreshing. White pepper, sage, leafy hops. Fluffy, super aerated palate. Quenching, very hoppy and leafy. Like a boss bottle of ES Bam. Very nice. Classic de Ranke or De la Senne profile. Excellent. 6/3/2012 8/5/7/5/15=4.0

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2013 Bottle at Capones. Pours a cloudy orange color with small tanish head. Funky JP sour notes, peach, oak, barnyard brett, fresh lemongrass. Taste is about the same with a slightly odd with a plastic or paint undertone mixed in with better notes of pineapple, leathery brett, pale and caramel malts and belgian spice. Very good.
At Capones. Pours golden orange with a white head. Floral hoppy and fruity aroma with some light grassy notes. The flavor has grassy and floral hops, and sweet fruity notes. Nice.

At Capones. Pours out a moderately cloudy orange/amber color with a small white head. Aroma is of slight funk, band-aid brett and some light citrus notes in there as well. Taste is of some citrusy notes, spice, light funky, some light plastic brett taste, some light citrus bitterness on the finish. Rather solid.

Glass, Labeled Bottle.

22 oz.

 Courtesy of James (JRedmond). 

This beer pops to life with a whisper and a hiss, pouring a beautifully deepy, hazy glowing orange with an initially massive, resistant, craggy tan head which recedes, leaving a seafoam crested surface. The lacing simply slides slowly down the shimmery sides of the snifter, ensnaring my scrupulous gaze. Oh, the nose. The bouqet of lovely, freshly picked delights which greets my nostrils like the sweetest summer breeze off the salty sea; strong must and sea air swirl through, leaving traces of freshly picked, plump, red delcious strawberries, gentle Brettanomyces yeast, slightly chewed Bazooka bubble gum, lemongrass, huge bailed and bundled dry hay, and truely special sourdough bread accents in its wake. As the beer washes over the tongue, it presents an inital tart, borderling sour, astringency, which, amazingly dissipates and evaportes from the tongue. The flavors left upon the palate are outrageous and the body a near perfection to behold; soft bubblegum, candied green apples, and spicy lemon zest swirl in a magnificently sturdy, yet roomy and fucking unclearly suave. This beer has no buisness being this good; it borders on the absurd. It is an area of human transcendence which, though some may dispute its very existence, is utterly invincible once experienced, truly. Today, drinking this scant, masterfully playful Belgian ale, brewed by some of the most inspired, rebellious, yet deeply respectful tradionalist brewers in the world, I am reminded of the permanancy of memory and the echo of existence. I may die, and this beer shall, too, pass--soon, Im afraid--but this moment; ah, this moment. It shall not perish from this realm so long as the stars fill the sky and until the known Universe collapse in itself. Amen, Halelujah, Omnipadi, Shanti Shanti Shanti. Cheers. Goodnight, angels of the human race. Be well, and take care of yourselves all.

5 June in the year 2011

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2011 Botle split with pat. Pours a hazy, but bright orange body with three fingers of huge frothy head that eventually dissipates into creamy, frothy lacing coating my glass. Aroma is cereal, sweet Belgian sugar, bubblegum, light funky tart, fruit. Mouthfeel is smoothly and ultimately very refreshing with notes of fruit - peach, nectarine, sweet bready malts, fresh citrus hops, pine, tart yeast and farmhouse funk. Great beer that blew me away.
Bottle. Pours hazy dark orange with a small white and creamy head. Aroma is solid hops fruity. Citrusy and peachy, light mango and sweet berry fruity. Wineous. Smooth fruity and mellow hoppy finish.

The pour reveals a cloudy golden color with a thick pillow of creamy beige froth. The hops provide a splendid exotic fruits aroma that accompanies rustic, wild brettanomyces and gentle peppery yeast. The flavor is damn good Ill say, theres exotic fruits provided by the hops while the brett adds a rustic, animal side to the beer, the yeast feels peppery. The body is full with a slightly creamy texture and medium carbonation. This is really impressive, amazing stuff.

On tap at the anniversary party.  Pours a hazed orange amber with a large white head.  Big fuzzy musk, toast.  Dry and  bretty funk.  Nice musk, and funky dry brett.  Leathery, long and full of yeast.  Dry lingering yeast.  Awesome.

Verre, au premier anniversaire de Hill Farmstead. Arômes très intenses de pamplemousse blanc, de fruits tropicaux. Légère présence de brettanomyces (bruxellensis ?). Robe orangée et légèrement trouble, belle mousse et effervescence moyenne. Très bien houblonnée et aromatique (agrumes, résine, fruits tropicaux). Les brettanomyces sont présents et apportent un agréable côté rustique mais, à ce jeune âge, le houblon est dominant. La bière présente une très belle texture moelleuse, sans être sucrée. Finale moyennement amère et très légèrement acide. Excellent !

On Tap at Hill Farmstead 1st Ann. 
Hazy peach pour, fluffy white head.  Aroma is tangy nectar fruit, sweet citrus, horsey pineapple.  Flavor is cool citrus, tart pineapple, some lightly bitter grassy hops, funky dry brett on the finish.  Funky Fresh.

On tap at HF first anniversary.
Appearance : Clear amber with huge white head.

Aroma :  Nice hops and brett. Nice funky and barnyard notes.

Taste : Citrusy hops with lots of brett. Light barnyard on finish.

Overall : Nice balance between hops and brett. Great citrusy notes. I liked the brett profile. Nice beer but its not exactly my thing. I could objectively rate a much higher.

On tap at Hill Farmsteads first anniversary celebration. A hazy straw pour gives way to an unyielding topographic frothy head. The aroma holds delicious lemon funk, cheesecloth, nectar fruits, and straw. The flavor follows suit with a beautiful nectar profile that twists in amazingly with subtle brett funk. Light, easy drinking palate with perfect carbonation. Nice.

On tap at Hill Farmsteads 1st Anniversary. Pours a beautiful hazy peach with a monstrous frothy head. Nose holds tons of nectar fruit, particularly apricot, along with mango and a wondrous tartness that meshes with the fruitiness beautifullly. Flavor is much of the same, with nectarine and pineapple mixing with an awesome sour presence. Palate is delicately but well carbonated and extremely refreshing. Top notch stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2016 Hazy Orange/Gold in colour with a massive 3 finger plus head.  Aroma of Pineapple, Grapefruit, a bit of Mango, oak, brett and belgian yeast.  Taste is very complex - Belgian yeast, grapefruit, lemon peel, mango, white grape, pineapple, lychee and a bit of pine and pepper and a very slight bit of barnyard funk - wonderful.  Light bodied and moderately carbonated.  Note - opened a bottle after a bit of aging - fruit fading very slightly and a stronger vinous note.

750ml bottle opened on May 7, 2011.

Sweet passionfruit, fresh orange juice, pineapple (brett), and a [mineral, earthy] bitterness. 

A single, fragrant flower grows at the node of each passionfruit: fresh-cut flowers - grassy and floral - grow out of the tropical and stone fruitiness mid-palate. Theres a pithy bitterness throughout the palate that is most noticeable on the finish, but it blends seamlessly into the other elements of the beer, and the fruitiness becomes more and more expressive the further I get into the bottle.

As with most good things, E. is, more than anything, ponderable.

The only further compliment I can give is this: E. will, if only for a few hours, strip you of your worldliness.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2017 My Bottom Line:
Pineapple, citrus fruit, brettanomyces and hop resins coalesce in this intense Wild Pale Ale, while horse stable undercurrents add to the impression of otherworldliness. 

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A clinging head of foam decorates the hazy dark blond.
-The fluffy mouthfeel created by the dryness and high volumes of carbonation increases the perception of funkiness in the finish.
-This finish was also resolutely bitter and resinous.
-All in all, this is yet another amazingly complex Belgian-style creature from Shaun. One which might cater to those looking for more intensity than that offered by Art or Flora, for example.
-This might very well be Orvals American cousin. Breathtaking, especially after the increase of drinkability a couple of months after its release.

Bottles and on tap at the brewery.
